sections.heading: Journal Name
sections.text:
ARTICLE
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx J. Name., 2013, 00, 1-3 | 1
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
Received 00th January 20xx, Accepted 00th January 20xx
DOI: 10.1039/x0xx00000x
www.rsc.org/
Fe/Fe3C@N-doped porous carbon hybrids derived from nano-
scale MOFs: robust and enhanced heterogeneous catalyst for
peroxymonosulfate activation
Tao Zeng, Mingdong Yu, Haiyan Zhang, Zhiqiao He, Jianmeng Chen and Shuang Song *
This study subtly integrates eco-friendly and cost-effective Fe-based nanoparticles (Fe/Fe3C NPs) with N-doped porous carbon (NC) to effectively activate peroxymonosulfate (PMS) and decompose target organic compounds in water. The Fe/Fe3C@NC hybrids can be facilely fabricated through one-pot pyrolysis Fe, N-contained nano-scale metal-organic framework (MOF). Benefiting from the excellent enrichment ability of NC matrix and abundant accessible sites arising from NPs and catalyst support, Fe/Fe3C@NC outperformed common oxides such as Co3O4 and Fe3O4 for PMS activation and organic compound degradation. With high saturation magnetization, the catalyst can then be easily recycled for next runs without significant capacity or activity loss. The applicability of this catalyst was also systematically assessed by means of the influence of the main factors and extent of mineralization. Through the mechanistic study, the active species in the system are identified as sulfate radicals (SO4 •- ) and hydroxyl radicals (OH • ), and the variable chemical valences of Fe NPs as well as pyridinic N and graphitic N in support contribute to the outstanding catalytic activity. Such findings elucidated a new opportunity for design of feasible platform to improve the overall catalytic activity in environmental remediation.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Serious water pollution as one of the key issues in environmental deterioration is faced by modern society. Effective water pollution mitigation with advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) in terms of full decomposition of the target pollutants through activation of various superoxides has been the subject of extensive research and is expected to be devoted into practical applications. 1-5 Similar to Fenton and Fenton-like processes, the method based on peroxymonosulfate (PMS) activation is a recently emerged AOP for the generation of strongly oxidizing sulfate radical (SO4 •- , E 0 = 2.5-3.1 V). 6-8 SO4 •- is flexible to a wider pH as well as has a higher redox potential than hydroxyl radical (OH • , E 0 = 1.8-2.7 V). 9, 10 Furthermore, benefiting from the advantages of easier storage, transportation and operation of PMS with respect to hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), SO4 •- based AOPs (SRAOPs) is becoming a promising alternative to conventional Fenton processes. 11, 12 Cobalt-based catalysts have been proved to be effective for activation of PMS. 13-15 However, cobalt leaching is a major barrier to practical application due to its potential carcinogenic effects. 16 As a consequence, the development of efficient and safe catalysts for PMS activation remains a priority.
Given that Fe-based heterogeneous catalysts are earth-
abundant, eco-friendly and cost-effective, 17 these materials are particularly considered to be suitable candidates for SRAOPs. 18-20 Moreover, Fe-based nanocatalysts usually present fantastic magnetically separable properties, which are of significant economic and environmental benefit owing to the reduced consumption of additional substances, energy, and time used for catalyst isolation from solution and recycling. 21, 22 Unfortunately, the majority of them are often plagued by weak catalytic activity and require additional electricity, 23 ultrasonics, 24 or light irradiation 25 for activity enhancement. Another issue of concern is that these catalysts are prone to agglomeration and the catalytic sites are damaged readily when directly exposed in bulk reaction solution. 26 To break through these limitations, either encapsulation of Fe-based nanoparticles (NPs) inside a special porous host materials or development of a protective shell is recognized. 27, 28 These represent an interesting category of heterogeneous catalysts with high efficiency and improved durability and is worthy of in-depth study.
Recently, nitrogen-doped (N-doped) carbon has been deemed as a superior candidate for catalyst support since doping the carbon network with N heteroatom can introduce electrocatalytic active sites and enhance the electrical conductivity. 29-31 Interestingly, some groups newly found that N-doped carbon materials show a certain capability to activate superoxides for the destruction of organic contaminants, 32, 33 although the overall performance is still far from satisfactory and the exact mechanism is unclear. These motivate us to

sections.heading: ARTICLE Journal Name
sections.text:
2 | J. Name., 2012, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
combine Fe-based NPs with N-doped carbon to form a hybrid that integrates their respective merits to enhance the SR-AOPs catalytic activity. Specifically, such a hybrid catalyst may involve the following advantages in comparison with the existing ones: 1) highly dispersed Fe-based NPs stabilized by Ndoped carbon may prevent them from aggregation; 34 2) the graphitic carbon may offer adsorptive domains for enrichment of organic pollutants in proximity to catalysts; 35 and 3) the synergistic effect arising from N-doped carbon and Fe-based NPs as separate catalytic active sites may boost the overall performance. Thus, attempts to design such kind of SR-AOPs catalysts are desirable but challenging.
Built out of metal ions and organic ligands, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as a relatively new class of crystalline porous materials have received growing interest and been applied in many fields. 36-38 With diversified composition and structural tenability, MOFs offer congenital conditions as templates to afford various metal and/or metal oxide NPs distributed throughout the porous carbon matrix, primarily via pyrolysis. 39-41 More importantly, the incorporation of N heteroatom into the carbon framework is more feasible than carbon nanotubes or graphene because it can be achieved by directly pyrolyzing N-containing group decorated MOFs. 42, 43 Although NPs embedded N-doped carbon hybrids derived from MOFs have attracted increasing attention as a platform for various applications, 44-49 report related to immobilization of Fe NPs on N-doped porous carbon derived from MOFs as SRAOPs catalysts for enhanced catalytic removal of organic pollutants, to the best of our knowledge, has scarcely been touched.
With these in mind, a representative Fe-based MOF, Fe-MIL88B-NH2, as both template and precursor has been thermally converted to Fe/Fe3C@N-doped porous carbon hybrid (Fe/Fe3C@NC) with regular shape, in which crystalline Fe/Fe3C NPs with a thin graphitic layer covered are dispersed throughout the NC matrix. The catalytic performance of the nanocomposites was evaluated by activation of PMS for pollutants removal. As expected, the resultant hybrids exhibited excellent catalytic activity and extraordinary magnetically recyclability. With the systematic investigations in respect of the influence of the main factors, extent of mineralization as well as the possible mechanism, we demonstrate such a catalyst holds great promise in practical environmental application.

sections.heading: Chemicals
sections.text:
2-Aminoterephthalic acid and 4-chlorophenol (4-CP) were obtained from Acros Organics (Morris Plains, NJ). Ferric chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O), acetic acid, tert-butyl alcohol (TBA) and ethanol were from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Pluronic F127 and peroxymonosulfate (PMS, 2KHSO5·KHSO4·K2SO4, Oxone) was supplied by Sigma-Aldrich. HPLC-grade methanol was supplied by Fisher Scientific (Fair Lawn, NJ). All chemicals were used as received without any further purification. Ultrapure water was
prepared in the laboratory using a Milli-Q SP reagent water system from Millipore (Milford, MA).

sections.heading: Synthesis of Fe/Fe3C@NC hybrids
sections.text:
The Fe-MIL-88B-NH2 MOF was first synthesized according to the previous report with slight modification. 50 Briefly, 0.64 g of F127 was dissolved in 53.4 mL of deionized water, followed by the addition of 6.6 mL of FeCl3·6H2O aqueous suspension (0.4 M). 0.6 mL of acetic acid was then added until the mixture was stirred for 1.5 h. After another stirring of 1.5 h, 0.24 g of 2- aminoterephthalic acid was mixed into the above resultant. The reaction proceeded for 2 h under continuous stirring. Subsequently, the homogeneous solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and sealed to heat at 110°C for 24 h, and then cooled to room temperature. The dark brown solid product was washed with ethanol several times to remove the unreacted reactants.
The obtained Fe-MIL-88B-NH2 products was activated under vacuum condition at 200°C for 24 h. Afterward, the Fe/Fe3C@NC hybrids were prepared by annealing the activated Fe-MIL-88B-NH2 products in a tube furnace at 900°C for 6 h at argon atmosphere. The scheme for the preparation route of Fe/Fe3C@NC hybrids is illustrated in Fig. 1.
Fig. 1 Schematic illustration of the synthesis of Fe/Fe3C@NC hybrids.

sections.heading: Catalytic activity test
sections.text:
The oxidation degradation of 4-CP with PMS activation was carried out to examine the catalytic activity and reusability of the Fe/Fe3C@NC catalyst. All the experiments were performed in a conical flask in the dark condition within a shaking table. The reactions were carried out in 4-CP aqueous solution (20 mg L -1 ) with a Fe/Fe3C@NC catalyst (0.2 g L -1 ) and PMS (2 g L -1 ) at room temperature without pH adjustment. At intervals of a certain time, 0.2 mL of mixture solution were taken out and quenched with excess pure methanol (0.2 mL), followed by centrifugation for the next analysis. Dionex ultimate 3000 HPLC (Dionex, Sunyvale, CA) with a PDA-100 photodiode array detector and an Acclaim 120 C18 column (5 um, 4.6 × 250 mm) was explored to determine the concentration of 4-CP. The mobile phase was composed of acetonitrile and water ( 70:30, v/v) at a flow rate of 1.0 mL min -1 with a column temperature of 30°C. TOC was measured by TOC/TN analyser (liquic TOCⅡ) (Elementar Corporation, Germany) with deionized water and 0.8% HCl as mobile phase. For the recycle tests, the hybrids was magnetically recovered, washed with deionized water, dried and used in the next run with the similar experimental conditions.
Characterization

sections.text:
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx J. Name., 2013, 00, 1-3 | 3
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
The morphologies of the synthesized materials were surveyed by JEM-2010 transmission electron microscope with an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry (TEM-EDX, JEOL, Japan) and scan electronic microscopy (SEM, Hitachi SU8020, Japan). XRay photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted by applying a Thermo Scientific ESCA-Lab-200i-XL spectrometer (Waltham, MA) with monochromatic Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV). X-Ray diffraction studies (XRD, PANalytical X’ Pert diffractometer, Almelo, Netherlands) were performed to characterize the crystal form by using a monochromatized X-ray beam with nickel-filtered Cu Kα radiation with 0.4° min -1 scan rate. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted on a Mettler Toledo TGA / DSC1 STAR e system (Columbus, OH). Samples were loaded into a pan and heated to 800°C at a rate of 10°C/min. FTIR spectra were taken in KBr pressed pellets on a Nicolet Thermo NEXUS 670 Infrared Fourier Transform Spectrometer (Waltham, MA). Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were studied at 77 K with a Quadrasorb™ SI Four Station Surface Area Analyzer and Pore Size Analyzer (Quantachrome Instruments, Boynton Beach, FL). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and Barrett-JoynerHalenda (BJH) model were utilized to calculate the specific surface areas and pore structural parameters, respectively. An EMS-plus EPR instrument from Bruker was employed to detect the free radicals captured by 5, 5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline (DMPO) during PMS activation, operating under the following conditions: center field, 3515 G; sweep width, 100 G; microwave frequency, 9.87 GHz; power setting, 18.75 mW; scan number, 3.
Fig. 2 TEM images of Fe-MIL-88B-NH2 NPs (a) and Fe/Fe3C@NC hybrids (b); SEM images (c) and elemental mapping (d) of Fe/Fe3C@NC hybrids; HRTEM image of Fe NP (e).

sections.heading: Physicochemical properties of the materials
sections.text:
Fe, N-containing MOF, Fe-MIL-88B-NH2, is chosen as an ideal template for preparation of Fe-based NPs encapsulated Ndoped carbon materials. The MOF was first solvothermally synthesized based on the mixture of FeCl3·6H2O, 2- aminoterephthalic acid, and F127, where the first two served as Fe, N precursor, respectively, while F127 was used to
control the growth of MOF NPs. The spindle-like Fe-MIL-88BNH2 NPs with uniform diameters of about 80 nm and lengths of 270 nm were facilely formed, as shown in Fig. 2a. Compared with usual micrometer-scale counterparts, the larger surfaceto-volume ratio of this nano-scale MOF material would benefit environmental application if the size of the pyrolytic products could be kept in same nanoscale. 51 After heat treatment at 900°C in argon for 6 h, Fe-MIL-88B-NH2 NPs were converted into carbonized NPs. From the TEM (Fig. 2b) and SEM images (Fig. 2c), both the shape and size of carbonized NPs remained almost intact except the new emergence of metal NPs within them, implying no collapse happened. The elemental mapping regarding the STEM-BF image of carbonized NPs (Fig. 2d) elucidates the co-existence and well-defined spatial distribution of C, N, and Fe species, which indicates the formation of Fe-based NPs as well as the N-doped carbon. High-resolution TEM (Fig. 2e) was used to further study the morphology of Fe-based NPs. The Fe NP has a d-spacing of crystalline lattices with 0.21 nm, corresponding to the (211) planes of the Fe3C phase. 34 Meanwhile, it can be observed that the NP is surrounded by a thin graphitized carbon shell with a shell thickness of about 4 nm. Recent research has reported that the core-shell structured catalysts consisting of transition metal carbide core and the graphitized carbon shell displayed significantly enhanced the electrocatalytic activity and stability. 52 Thus, such a structure of small Fe-based NPs (~20 nm) uniformly embedded in N-doped carbon matrix could effectively keep the NPs stable, and give full scope to respective roles or synergistic effect of the two components, which would render the hybrids excellent in catalytic oxidation.
Fig.3 XRD spectra (a) and FTIR spectra (b) of Fe-MIL-88B-NH2 and Fe/Fe3C@NC samples.
The crystal structures of the samples are further explored by XRD survey (Fig. 3a). Fe-MIL-88B-NH2 products exhibit numerous diffraction peaks with the highest intensity at 9.8°, which is in accordance with previous report. In the case of Fe/Fe3C@NC, the peak at 26.5° corresponding to the (002) plane of graphitic carbon is observed, providing a supportive evidence for the presence of particular graphitic structures. The two peaks at around 45° and 65° can be assigned to the (110) and (200) reflections of α-Fe, respectively (JCPDS, No. 870722). The rest of diffraction peaks are characteristics of the crystalline planes of Fe3C species (JCPDS, No. 892867), which is consistent with the result of HRTEM. Raman spectrum was also used to characterize the formed Fe/Fe3C@NC hybrids. Fig. S1 shows the well-documented D band at 1320 cm -1 and G band

sections.heading: ARTICLE Journal Name
sections.text:
4 | J. Name., 2012, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
at 1580 cm -1 , matching with the disordered graphitic carbon and the vibration of the sp 2 -bonded carbon atoms in a twodimensional hexagonal lattice, respectively, which further confirms the formation of graphitic carbon during the pyrolysis process. The high ratio of integrated intensity of the D and G band (ID/IG) indicate the formation of abundant defects and disorders of graphitized structures due to the substitution of N atoms and the decrease in average size of the sp 2 domains upon the generation of NPs on the carbon matrix. 53 These results therefore prove that the hybrids consist of the graphitic carbon and Fe/Fe3C NPs.
To obtain insights into the formation of Fe/Fe3C@NC, TGA analysis was performed on samples (Fig. S2). For Fe-MIL-88BNH2 sample, the first weight loss of 17.2% wt.% at 40 - 220 °C, which is attributed to the release of physisorbed solvent molecules. The following larger weight loss of 59.3 wt.% at 220 - 320 °C can be put down to the partial decomposition of organic ligands and F127. When heated to 800 °C, the organic molecules completely decomposed, resulting in a weight loss of nearly 80 wt.%. While for Fe/Fe3C@NC, the sample do not exhibit obvious weight loss upon to at least 450 °C, and the final weight loss reaches to 28.4 wt.%. During the formation of Fe/Fe3C@NC, the released Fe ions from MOF may serve as a catalyst to promote the graphitization reactions of organic carbon. In addition, FTIR spectra for Fe-MIL-88B-NH2 samples before and after carbonization were also recorded (Fig. 3b). Two bands at around 3490 and 3370 cm -1 that are attributed to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching absorptions of primary amine groups can be observed in the spectrum of FeMIL-88B-NH2. After carbonization, amine groups together with almost all the oxygen-containing groups in the spectrum of Fe/Fe3C@NC disappear. The broad absorption between 400- 900 cm -1 and 1200-1600 cm -1 can be assigned to the out-ofplane bending mode for graphite-like sp 2 domains and aromatic C-N heterocycles stretching vibrations, respectively.
The pore character and surface area of the pyrolysis products were characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption measurements. The synthesized Fe/Fe3C@NC possess an increased surface area of 160 m 2 g -1 with uniform pore sizes of around 3.8 nm (Fig. 4b) in comparison to Fe-MIL-88B-NH2 with a surface area of 160 m 2 g -1 and a wide pore size distribution of 2.2-12.0 nm (Fig. 4a). The changes in the porosity and surface area must be originated from the removal of F127 surfactant, which was confirmed by the results of TGA analysis. Such high porosity (0.32 cm 3 g -1 ) and surface area would allow the exposure of active sites as far as possible and facilitate the facile adsorption and transportation of catalytic substrates. To explore potential of environmental applications, it is very interesting to study the magnetic properties of materials because magnetically separation could reduce the consumption of additional substances, energy, and time used for catalyst recycling. Fig. S3 illustrates the M-H hysteresis loop of Fe/Fe3C@NC measured by scanning the external field
between -1 and 1 T. It can be seen that its magnetization curves exhibits a hysteresis loop, revealing the ferromagnetic character of the prepared hybrid. Saturation magnetization that typically comes from the Fe/Fe3C NPs is measured to be 82.0 emu g -1 , which is strong enough to endow magnetically separable nature with Fe/Fe3C@NC catalyst.
Fig. 4 N2 adsorption-desorption spectra of Fe-MIL-88B-NH2 (a) and Fe/Fe3C@NC (b) samples; XPS wide scan surveys of FeMIL-88B-NH2 (c) and Fe/Fe3C@NC (d) samples.
The surface elemental composition of formed Fe/Fe3C@NC
is also analysed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Fig. 4d indicates that the resultant sample is composed of C, N, O, and Fe, with average contents of ∼87.3 wt %, ∼1.8 wt %, ∼5.0 wt % and ∼5.8 wt %, respectively. Compared with Fe-MIL-88BNH2 sample (Fig. 4c), the C content in Fe/Fe3C@NC is increased by ∼33.0 wt %, whereas the content of N, O, Fe is decreased by ∼2.9 wt %, ∼24.5 wt %, and ∼5.6 wt %, respectively, evidencing that N, O, and Fe are partially lost after carbonization. The C 1s core-level spectrum can be divided into several characteristic peaks, in which the peak at peak at 284.0 eV corresponds to the C-C bond from sp 2 -hybridized graphitic carbon and the peaks at around 286.0 and 288.0 eV are assigned to carbon in C-O and C-N bonds, respectively (Fig. 5b). In contrast to Fe-MIL-88B-NH2 precursors (Fig. 5a), the signal of sp 2 carbon of Fe/Fe3C@NC is fairly increased accompanied by weakened signals of carbon in C-O and C-N bonds, suggesting partial loss of O- and N-based functional groups after pyrolysis, which is consistent with the element analysis results. Disintegration of N 1s core-level spectrum reveals that pyridinic, graphitic and oxidized-type N have displaced amino-type N after the conversion of Fe-MIL-88BNH2 into Fe/Fe3C@NC (Fig. 5c, d). This alternation should be originated from cyclization reactions, and thus the nitrogen atoms would be incorporated in five- or six-membered rings 54 .

Fig. 5 XPS C 1s core-level spectra of Fe-MIL-88B-NH2 (a) and Fe/Fe3C@NC (b); XPS N 1s core-level spectra of Fe-MIL-88BNH2 (c) and Fe/Fe3C@NC (d) samples.

sections.heading: Catalytic performance
sections.text:
To investigate the catalytic performance of the as-prepared catalysts, oxidation degradation of 4-chlorophenol (4-CP) by activated PMS was chosen as a model reaction, and a set of control experiments were conducted. As shown in Fig. 6, PMS itself is inactive toward 4-CP degradation without a solid catalyst. Meanwhile, Fe/Fe3C@NC alone only showed a limited performance of 4-CP removal (about 20%) even after shaking 210 min due to adsorption. Notably, 4-CP could be almost completely removed within 90 min using Fe/Fe3C@NC hybrids as catalyst to activate PMS, implying that 4-CP was mainly degraded rather than adsorbed on the catalyst. This phenomenon indicates that Fe/Fe3C@NC hybrid coupled with PMS is an effective system for the degradation of organic pollutants. For comparison, hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) that is the common oxidant in Fenton-like reaction was used to test the degradation efficiency of the target organic compound in terms of the Fe/Fe3C@NC catalyst. Addition of H2O2 does cause 4-CP removal but the performance is not as much as that of PMS, which means the symmetrical structure of H2O2 makes it cannot be activated as readily as PMS that possesses unsymmetrical character. This result was in line with the homogeneous and heterogeneous catalytic oxidation in other studies. Moreover, two metal oxides (Co3O4 and Fe3O4) that mentioned frequently as SR-AOPs catalysts in literatures were employed as references for the reaction under the same experimental conditions. Fe3O4 presents negligible catalytic activity while Co3O4 leads to 40% of 4-CP removal within 90 min with PMS, which are far less than the performance of Fe/Fe3C@NC catalyst, elucidating that the as-prepared hybrid is the most active catalyst among them. Also, Fe/Fe3C@NC hybrids exhibit superior catalytic performance to N-doping graphene and graphitic carbon@Co composites that prepared in our previous work under same conditions (Table S1). In
order to clarify the role of Fe-based NPs in the hybrid on catalytic reaction controlled experiments using Fe/Fe3C@NC after etching with a lower Fe/Fe3C loading were performed. The Fe/Fe3C@NC after
Fig. 6 Removal of 4-CP under different conditions: (1) PMS alone, (2) Fe/Fe3C@NC alone, (3) Fe/Fe3C@NC with H2O2, (4) Co3O4 with PMS, (5) Fe3O4 with PMS, (6) acid-treated Fe/Fe3C@NC with PMS, and (7) Fe/Fe3C@NC with PMS. Other reaction parameters: initial 4-CP 20 mg L -1 , PMS 2 g L -1 , T = 298 K, catalyst dosage 0.2 g L −1 , without pH adjustment.
etching exhibits a much lower efficiency (85% of 4-CP degradation within 90 min) than the Fe/Fe3C@NC. The decrease in degradation efficiency of the targets on Fe/Fe3C@NC after etching indicates that the removal of Fe/Fe3C NPs using acid treatment definitely affects the catalytic activity. Recently, some researchers including our group have found that N-doped carbon materials are able to activate PMS for decomposition of pollutants regardless of the unclear mechanism. 55, 56 Thus, the above results together with the previous reports suggest that the high catalytic performance of Fe/Fe3C@NC is probably attributed to the coexistence of Fe/Fe3C species and NC, which are the active sites for catalytic reaction. However, the dominant contribution between Fe/Fe3C species and NC is difficult to determine since Fe/Fe3C NPs are hard to be totally removed and NC with such morphology cannot be directly prepared in this work.
Further investigations were performed to evaluate the effect of reaction parameters on the 4-CP degradation in Fe/Fe3C@NC-PMS system, and a general pseudo first order kinetics was employed to estimate reaction rates at each parameter. Fig. S4a displays the impact of initial 4-CP concentration on the degradation efficiency. The 4-CP removal efficiency tended to drop quickly with increasing initial 4-CP contents in solution. Within 60 min, it can reach about 98%, 93%, 83%, and 43% at the initial 4-CP concentration of 10, 20, 30, and 50 mg L -1 , respectively. The corresponding rate constants are 0.043, 0.041, 0.029, and 0.006 min -1 . The intractability in higher initial concentration may be ascribed to the limited dosage of PMS and the coverage of excess 4-CP molecules on the active sites of the catalyst. On the contrary, higher dosage of catalyst results in superior degradation

efficiency (Fig. S4b). At 0.3 g L -1
of Fe/Fe3C@NC, it only took 60
min for ∼100% degradation of 4-CP. More active sites in the system undoubtedly give rise to the enhancement of catalytic efficiency. Solution pH can remarkably affect the Fenton-like reaction. Fig. S4c illustrates that fast removal of 4-CP can be achieved over an initial pH range of 4.0 to 11.0 in this process, indicating that Fe/Fe3C@NC-PMS system could be work in a
Fig. 7 The efficiency of TOC removal during the degradation of 4-CP (a), and the reusability of Fe/Fe3C@NC catalyst (b).
wider pH range as compared to conventional Fenton reaction. Based on this result, pH adjustment is not needed before the reaction. The slight decrease of removal efficiency when pH increased to 11 probably originate from the generation of less oxidative SO5 2- as PMS is in such an alkaline condition. 57 Moreover, with increasing the PMS concentration, 4-CP degradation can be enhanced significantly (Fig. S4d). The removal efficiency of 4-CP in 90 min increased from 62% to 99% with the dosage of PMS increasing from 0.5 to 2.0 g L -1 . However, further increasing PMS concentration will not obviously promote the degradation any more, possibly due to the limitation of the quantity of active sites for PMS activation.
The profile of TOC removal with reaction time was also investigated to reflect the change of mineralization degree of 4-CP during the oxidation process. As shown in Fig. 7a, the TOC reduction proceeded much more slowly than did the removal of 4-CP owing to the generation of various intermediates that have been confirmed in our previous work. 10 Eventually, the mineralization reached to 67% after 210 min, and the residual TOC may be ascribed to some recalcitrant small molecular carbolic acids produced during reaction. To distinguish the possible contribution of the leachate to the reaction, filtrate from solid catalyst suspension being shaken for a certain time was applied to catalyze the degradation of 4-CP. Almost no 4- CP removal was observed, implying the degradation of 4-CP mainly occurs in a heterogeneous reaction rather than a homogeneous reaction.

sections.heading: Reusability of the catalyst
sections.text:
A critical issue with regard to the general applicability of the catalyst is the reusability and stability in the operating process. To assess the reusability and stability of the Fe/Fe3C@NC catalyst, four consecutive rounds of the degradation reaction for 4-CP were conducted under the same reaction conditions. Fig. S5 shows that the synthesized Fe/Fe3C@NC hybrids dispersed in a water solution can be magnetically isolated from the suspension and the cloudy suspended solution turns transparent within a few seconds with an external magnet.
Therefore, the catalyst was recovered from the reaction medium using a magnet at the end of each cycle. Although the activity of the catalyst dropped slightly in the last cycles, a high catalytic activity with a 4-CP degradation degree of 92.5% could still be achieved within 120 min in the fourth cycle (Fig. 7b). The slight decline in removal efficiency may be caused by the loss of the catalysts during the recovery process. Furthermore, SEM, FTIR, and XPS measurements were conducted to check the possible change of Fe/Fe3C@NC catalyst before and after use and the results showed no significant change in morphology and surface composition (Fig. S6), indicating the catalyst remained very well. The good stability and reusability therefore render the Fe/Fe3C@NC catalyst hold great promise for water treatment application.

sections.heading: Reaction mechanism of the system
sections.text:
The involved radical species were probed by radical scavenger experiments. It is well accepted that OH • and SO4 •- can be generated in heterogeneous activation of PMS. 58 OH • is able to be quenched by both ethanol and tert-butyl alcohol (TBA), while SO4 •- tend to react with ethanol rather than TBA that without α-H. On account of this different behaviour, ethanol and TBA were used to ascertain the radical type in the reaction. The inhibition effects of the two quenchers on the 4-CP degradation in Fe/Fe3C@NC-PMS system were depicted in Fig. 8a. Without quencher, about 100% 4-CP was degraded within 90 min. The removal of 4-CP was obviously decreased when TBA added, suggesting a number of OH • should be produced in this system. In the meantime, addition of ethanol vastly inhibited the degradation of 4-CP. The above results manifest that the main radical intermediates involved in the activation of PMS by Fe/Fe3C@NC hybrids were OH • and SO4 •- . To further confirm the identity of the involved reactive species, the EPR experiments that using a typical spin trapping agent, DMPO, to capture the generated radicals were carried out. As shown in Fig. 8b, negligible radicals were generated by PMS itself and catalyst alone, while strong EPR signals appeared in the catalyst/PMS system, revealing the production of plenty of reactive radicals in the reaction. Both SO4 •- and OH • were confirmed, and the latter were of a relatively higher intensity. The signal intensity of the reaction proceeded in 15 min were a little higher than that of the reaction proceeded in 5 min. The EPR results strongly suggest that Fe/Fe3C@NC catalyst is available for activation of PMS to generate OH • and SO4 •- , which is well consistent with the quenching experiment results.

sections.heading: Journal Name ARTICLE
sections.text:
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx J. Name., 2013, 00, 1-3 | 7
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
The high resolution curve-fitted elementary XPS analysis of the Fe/Fe3C@NC catalyst before and after used was also performed for a better insight of the activation mechanism of PMS. For XPS spectra of the fresh sample in the Fe 2p core level (Fig. 9a), Fe 0 (707.3 eV), Fe 3+ (710.8 and 713.2 eV), and shake-up satellite Fe 2p3/2 (719.5 eV) were identified. After being used, the photoelectron peak of metal iron (Fe 0 ) almost disappeared, while the Fe 3+ component with a slightly positive shift (711.1 and 713.3 eV) still existed. The vanishment of metal iron component suggests that most of the Fe 0 on the surface of the catalyst has been oxidized to Fe 3+ during the catalytic reaction with PMS. The small shift of Fe 2p further reveals that Fe-based NPs did participate in the redox reaction of electron transfer in the catalytic process. The C 1s core level has been fitted to four components at ∼284.7, ∼285.7, ∼286.5, and ∼290.0 eV, corresponding to C-C, C-OH, C-O-C, C=O groups, respectively (Fig. 9b). Comparing the fitted C 1s spectra of the hybrid before and after reaction, it can be found that the relative proportion of C-OH in C 1s increased from 27% to 29% after the reaction, implying the surface hydroxylation of the hybrid in the Fenton-like process. Similar results have been found in the fitted O 1s core-level spectra (Fig. 9c). Four peaks with binding energy positioned at 530.2, 531.4, 532.2, and 533.2 eV, with relative contributions to the overall O intensity of 35%, 17%, 25%, and 23%, could be assigned to C=O, C-OH, C-C=O, and C-O-C, respectively. However, the relative contributions of these four peaks after reaction are 47%, 29%, 13%, and 11%. The apparent increase of C-OH in O 1s provides a supportive evidence for the surface hydroxylation of Fe/Fe3C@NC catalyst during the reaction.
Fig. 9 XPS Fe 2p (a), C 1s (b), O 1s (c), and N 1s (d) of Fe/Fe3C@NC hybrids before and after reaction.
It has been demonstrated that the involvement of graphitic N and pyridinic N in carbon materials is favourable to improve the electrochemical performance. 54, 59 Duan et al. suggested that the graphitic N in graphene can enhance the interaction between PMS and graphene and activate the O-O bond in PMS to generate active radicals. 60 The XPS spectra of N 1s are
deconvoluted to three contributions at 398.4, 401.2, and 404 eV, with relative contents of 7%, 58%, and 35%, attributed to pyridinic, graphitic and oxidized-type N, respectively (Fig. 9d). After the catalytic reaction, the pyridinic N and graphitic N decreased to 4% and 53%, manifesting that the doped N in Fe/Fe3C@NC catalyst play a key role in PMS activation. Considering that the heteroatom dopants would activate the adjacent carbons to make carbon materials work as active sites for PMS excitation and dramatically improve the catalytic performance, we believe the N-doped carbon matrix in this work can also enhance the number of active sites.
On the basis of the above results and previous studies, a possible mechanism of 4-CP degradation in Fe/Fe3C@NC-PMS system was proposed (Fig. 10). 4-CP and PMS molecular were first enriched from the bulk solution by N-doped carbon matrix due to the π-π interaction and chemical adsorption, respectively, leading to a high local concentration of reactants around the catalyst. The Fe-based NPs with variable chemical valences are able to transfer electrons and serve as the active site to activate PMS. Meanwhile, the N-doped carbon sites can also facilitate electron transfer for PMS activation on carbon matrix. Also, transition metal NPs are reported to be easily interact with nitrogen and oxygen to form intimate bonds (probably Fe-Nx, Fe-Ox in this work), which may create more active sites for enhancing the catalytic performance 61 . Finally, the reactive species (OH • , SO4 •- ) generated in the activation of PMS oxidatively decomposed 4-CP to small molecular substances, entirely releasing the occupied sites of the catalyst as free sites. Therefore, the synergistic effects between Fe NPs and N-doped carbon make the Fe/Fe3C@NC catalyst present an excellent catalytic activity for SR-AOPs without the necessity of additional electricity or light irradiation.
Fig. 10 Possible reaction mechanism of 4-CP degradation in the Fe/Fe3C@NC-PMS system.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, a facile route has been developed to fabricate a novel SR-AOPs catalyst with Fe/Fe3C NPs embedded in NC matrix by one-pot pyrolysis of nano-scale Fe, N-contained MOF. The as-prepared hybrids were demonstrated to possess superior catalytic activity and reusability toward organic compound degradation in the presence of PMS due to the highly enrichment ability and abundant active sites. Mechanistic study suggested that the generated OH • and SO4 •- during the activation processes of PMS are the main active

species while Fe surface valence changes and N-doped sites in matrix played important roles for the remarkable performance. These findings make the hybrids as new SR-AOPs catalyst hold significant potential for application in remediation of organic pollutants in water.
